questions.text: A 75-year-old man with a history of bioprosthetic aortic valve replacement presents with intermittent fever and dyspnea 3 years after the procedure. TTE is normal. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE)

 

Option C:

 

TEE is more sensitive than TTE for detecting vegetations on prosthetic valves and is recommended for patients with suspected prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cardiac CT: Less sensitive than TEE for detecting vegetations.

 

Option B. Cardiac MRI: Not the first-line imaging modality for PVE.

 

Option D. No further testing: Inappropriate given the suspicion for PVE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with suspected infective endocarditis, transthoracic echocardiography is recommended as the initial imaging choice in most clinical situations.

 

TEE is the preferred imaging modality to evaluate for PVE when TTE is inconclusive or if complications have developed or are clinically suspected or if intracardiac device leads are present, transesophageal echocardiography is recommended.

choices.text: Colchicine and intravenous immune globulin (IVIG)

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is evaluated for recurrent pericarditis. He has had two prior episodes, both successfully treated with ibuprofen and colchicine. His current symptoms include fever, pulsus paradoxus, a pericardial friction rub, and widespread ST-segment elevation on ECG. Echocardiogram shows a small pericardial effusion without tamponade. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ibuprofen, colchicine, and prednisone

 

Option D:

 

This patient has recurrent pericarditis, defined as a recurrence after a symptom-free interval of 4-6 weeks following the initial episode. Since he has already been treated with ibuprofen and colchicine, the most appropriate treatment for this recurrence is triple therapy with ibuprofen, colchicine, and a glucocorticoid like prednisone. This combination has been shown to be more effective in reducing recurrence rates compared to colchicine and NSAIDs alone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anakinra: This is an interleukin-1 receptor antagonist used for refractory cases of recurrent pericarditis that have not responded to other treatments.

 

Option B. Colchicine and IVIG: This combination is also used for refractory cases, but glucocorticoids should be added first.

 

Option C. Ibuprofen alone: Unlikely to be effective for recurrent pericarditis, especially since it has been used previously.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with recurrent pericarditis initially treated with both colchicine and an NSAID, the addition of a glucocorticoid should be considered.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man had an atrial septal defect (ASD) closure one year ago. He is now scheduled for tooth extraction and periodontal cleaning. The dentist recommended a nil per oral (NPO) 8 hours prior to the procedure. What is the choice for IE prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No endocarditis prophylaxis

 

Option D:

 

IE prophylaxis is not recommended for patients with repaired ASDs who do not have residual shunts or other high-risk features.

 

IE prophylaxis is indicated only for patients at high risk for infective endocarditis who are about to undergo gingival manipulation or other procedures that break the oral mucosa.

 

The highest risk for IE is in patients with a prosthetic valve, previous IE, or cyanotic congenital heart disease or repaired congenital heart disease with residual flow disturbances. Other indications include cardiac transplantation valvulopathy, prosthetic material used for cardiac valve repair, and a cardiac defect that has been repaired with prosthetic material within the previous 6 months.

 

Explanation:

 

A), B), C): These are antibiotics used for endocarditis prophylaxis but are not indicated in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endocarditis prophylaxis is not routinely recommended for dental procedures in patients with repaired ASDs unless there are specific high-risk features.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman presents with progressive dyspnea, cough, weight loss, and pulsus paradoxus. Physical exam reveals jugular venous distention, distant heart sounds, and crackles. Chest X-ray shows a large right upper lobe mass and an enlarged cardiac silhouette. What is the next test?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE)

 

Option D:

 

The combination of pulsus paradoxus, distant heart sounds, and enlarged cardiac silhouette on chest X-ray strongly suggests cardiac tamponade. TTE is the most appropriate initial test as it can rapidly diagnose pericardial effusion and tamponade, which is a life-threatening condition requiring urgent intervention.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CT-guided needle biopsy: May be needed later to assess the lung mass, but not the immediate priority.

 

Option B. Fiberoptic bronchoscopy: May be useful for evaluating the lung mass, but not the priority in this unstable patient.

 

Option C. PET/CT: May be useful for staging malignancy, but not the immediate priority.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Findings suggesting cardiac tamponade include pulsus paradoxus, tachycardia, distant heart sounds, and occasionally an enlarged silhouette on CXR.

 

Echocardiography is an essential tool in the diagnosis of cardiac tamponade because it defines the presence, distribution, and relative volume of pericardial fluid.

questions.text: A patient evaluated for cough is found to have an enlarged cardiac silhouette on chest radiography. He is suspected of having pericardial effusion. Ultrasonography is performed with the probe placed in the subxiphoid area. The results are shown. Which of the following is the most likely interpretation of this study?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Large pericardial effusion

 

Option A:

 

This patient's ultrasound shows a large, circumferential pericardial effusion (arrows) with evidence of cardiac tamponade. An anechoic space is seen between the liver in the near field and the myocardium of the heart and also surrounds the entire heart, indicating a large effusion. Cardiac tamponade is typically seen as collapse of the right atrium or the right ventricle during the diastolic phase of the cardiac cycle. In this study, although the right ventricular free wall appears to “wiggle,” this is caused by inward diastolic movement typical in tamponade.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. No pericardial effusion: This option is incorrect because the ultrasound clearly demonstrates the presence of a significant anechoic space around the heart, indicating a pericardial effusion.

 

Option C. LV dilatation: Left ventricular (LV) dilatation is not indicated by the findings described in this scenario. The primary abnormality is the pericardial effusion, not an intrinsic abnormality of the left ventricle.

 

Option D. Indeterminate study: This option is incorrect because the ultrasound findings are definitive for a large pericardial effusion. There is no indication that the study is inconclusive or indeterminate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A large pericardial effusion is characterized by the accumulation of fluid around the heart, visible as an anechoic space on ultrasound. It can lead to cardiac tamponade, a life-threatening condition that requires prompt recognition and management.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with SLE presents with progressive dyspnea, fatigue, chest fullness, and bilateral peripheral edema. She is febrile and her JVP is elevated. ECG is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiac tamponade

 

The patient's clinical presentation, including fever, jugular venous distention and electrical alternans on ECG are suggestive of cardiac tamponade. Cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening condition where fluid accumulation in the pericardial sac compresses the heart, impairing its ability to pump blood.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Constrictive pericarditis: Although it can present with similar symptoms, it usually has a more insidious onset and does not typically cause electrical alternans on ECG.

 

Option C. Pulmonary embolism: Can cause dyspnea and elevated JVP, but it would not typically present with electrical alternans.

 

Option D. Pulmonary hypertension: Less likely in the absence of lung disease or right heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Electrical alternans is a hallmark of cardiac tamponade.

choices.text: CT scan of the chest

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-week history of fever and malaise. Nail findings show splinter hemorrhages. Which of the following is the next appropriate step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blood cultures

 

Option A:

 

The image demonstrates splinter hemorrhages which are common in patients with infective endocarditis. Hence, the next appropriate step would be to obtain blood cultures.

 

Note: Splinter hemorrhages are subungual linear pigmented streaks following the long axis of the nail; most are located at the distal one third of the nail. Their color changes from purple to brown or black as they age. Trauma is the most common cause of splinter hemorrhages. Other causes include infective endocarditis, arterial emboli, trichinosis, scurvy, and psoriasis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Urine cultures: While urine cultures may be helpful in identifying a urinary tract infection, they are not the primary diagnostic test for suspected IE.

 

Option C. CT scan of the chest: A CT scan might be helpful in later stages to assess for complications of IE, such as embolic events, but blood cultures are the first step.

 

Option D. CSF analysis: CSF analysis is used to diagnose infections of the central nervous system, not IE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Splinter hemorrhages in the setting of fever and malaise raise the suspicion of infective endocarditis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-day history of fever, malaise, and heart murmur. Today, crops of nonpainful cutaneous lesions have appeared on his feet as shown. Given the diagnosis, the patient is at risk of all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aortic dissection

 

Option D:

 

The image demonstrates Janeway lesions. These are nonpainful, macular (occasionally nodular), blanching lesions located on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet; they  are associated with infective endocarditis and considered to be a part of vascular phenomenon.

 

Coming back to the case - fever, malaise and a new heart murmur also strongly suggests infective endocarditis. While IE can rarely cause mycotic aneurysms (common the brain), aortic dissection is not a direct complication of infective endocarditis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Intracranial hemorrhage: Septic emboli from IE can lodge in the brain, causing intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Option B. Stroke: Septic emboli can also cause ischemic stroke.

 

Option C. Heart failure: Valve damage from IE can lead to heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic complications are uncommon in endocarditis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is evaluated for chronic right-sided heart failure. Chest radiographs are shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Constrictive pericarditis

 

Option B:

 

The most likely diagnosis is constrictive pericarditis. This chest radiograph shows pericardial calcification on both the posterior-anterior (black arrow) and lateral views (white arrows). Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by pericardial thickening, fibrosis, and sometimes calcification that impair diastolic filling and limit total cardiac volume. Chest radiography or CT may demonstrate partial or circumferential pericardial calcification, and CT or cardiac magnetic resonance imaging may demonstrate pericardial thickening (>3 mm). Importantly, constriction may exist in the absence of these findings.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension: This condition involves pulmonary artery obstruction due to organized clots, leading to increased pulmonary artery pressure and right-sided heart failure. However, it would not typically present with pericardial calcification on chest radiographs.

 

Option C. Primary hyperparathyroidism: While primary hyperparathyroidism can cause hypercalcemia and possibly lead to calcifications in various tissues, it is not typically associated with pericardial calcification or the symptoms of chronic right-sided heart failure.

 

Option D. Restrictive cardiomyopathy: Restrictive cardiomyopathy causes diastolic dysfunction due to myocardial stiffness but does not involve pericardial calcification. The imaging findings and clinical presentation are more consistent with constrictive pericarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by pericardial thickening and calcification that leads to impaired cardiac filling and chronic right-sided heart failure. Radiographic evidence of pericardial calcification is a key diagnostic clue.

choices.text: They are associated with infective endocarditis.
They are caused by immune complex deposition.
They can be found on the fingertips and toes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-week history of subjective fever and malaise. A grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur that increases with inspiration is present at the left mid-sternal border. A new, painful skin lesion is shown. Which of the following is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) They are typically painless.

 

Option B:

 

Osler's nodes are painful, tender, erythematous nodules typically located on the fingertips or toes. They are a classic sign of infective endocarditis, caused by immune complex deposition in the skin.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. They are associated with infective endocarditis: This is true. Osler's nodes are a cutaneous manifestation of infective endocarditis.

 

Option C. They are caused by immune complex deposition: This is true. The pathogenesis of Osler's nodes involves the deposition of immune complexes in the skin, leading to inflammation and the formation of the nodules.

 

Option D. They can be found on the fingertips and toes: This is true. Osler's nodes are most commonly found on the pads of the fingers and toes, but they can also occur on other parts of the hands and feet.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osler's nodes as a painful, cutaneous manifestation of infective endocarditis caused by immune complex deposition.

questions.text: A 77-year-old man is evaluated for a 10-day history of fever and fatigue. Two years ago, he underwent dual-chamber pacemaker implantation. He reports tenderness at the site of his pacemaker, as shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Device-associated infection

 

Option B:

 

The most likely diagnosis is device-associated infection. The image depicts device erosion through the skin. Device-associated infections have many different forms, ranging from pocket infections to endocarditis. Most infections are caused by Staphylococcus epidermidis and Staphylococcus aureus. Symptoms of cardiac device infection include fever, chills, malaise, lassitude, and failure to thrive. Physical examination of the pocket may reveal erythema, swelling, drainage, wound dehiscence, or device erosion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma: Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma typically presents as a persistent, non-healing ulcer or nodule with a rough or scaly surface. It would not be associated with the systemic symptoms (fever, fatigue) described here, nor with tenderness at the site of a previously implanted device.

 

Option C. Pyoderma gangrenosum: Pyoderma gangrenosum is a rare inflammatory condition that typically presents with painful, rapidly progressing ulcers with a purulent base and violaceous borders. It is associated with systemic diseases like inflammatory bowel disease and rheumatoid arthritis, not with pacemaker implantation.

 

Option D. Pyogenic granuloma: Pyogenic granuloma is a benign vascular lesion that typically appears as a small, red, rapidly growing nodule or mass, often after minor trauma. It would not typically present with systemic symptoms like fever or tenderness at a pacemaker site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A device-associated infection can occur after implantation of devices like pacemakers and may present with systemic symptoms such as fever, along with local signs like tenderness, erythema, and even erosion of the device through the skin.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with edema and ascites. On examination, he has elevated JVP with no respiratory variation. His BP is 110/70 mmHg and decreases to 80/60 mmHg with inspiration. 2D echo revealed a large pericardial effusion. Pericardiocentesis was performed, but intracardiac pressures remain elevated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Effusive-constrictive pericarditis

 

Option C:

 

This condition combines features of both constrictive pericarditis and cardiac tamponade. The presence of a pericardial effusion with elevated intracardiac pressures initially suggests cardiac tamponade. However, the persistence of elevated intracardiac pressures after pericardiocentesis indicates a component of constrictive pericarditis, where the thickened pericardium restricts ventricular filling.

 

Also, this patient has a combination of kussmaul’s sign and pulsus paradoxus initially suggesting the presence of both constriction and effusion.

 

NSAIDs and colchicine are first-line therapy in such cases, and close follow-up is recommended.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Constrictive pericarditis: This would present with elevated intracardiac pressures, but there wouldn't be a significant pericardial effusion.

 

Option B. Cardiac tamponade: This would also present with elevated intracardiac pressures, but these pressures would normalize after pericardiocentesis.

 

Option D. Dilated cardiomyopathy: This presents with a dilated left ventricle and reduced ejection fraction, and typically does not have elevated intracardiac pressures or pericardial effusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Effusive-constrictive pericarditis is a combination of pericardial effusion and constrictive pericarditis, characterized by persistently elevated intracardiac pressures even after drainage of the effusion.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with chronic kidney disease shortness of breath and diaphoresis. BP is 90/60 mm Hg and it decreases to 70/50 during inspiration. On examination, his JVP is elevated, has pitting pedal edema and heart sounds were faint. What is the next management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pericardiocentesis

 

Option C:

 

Tamponade occurs when intrapericardial pressure exceeds diastolic intracardiac pressures, which leads to compression of cardiac chambers and limits diastolic filling, stroke volume, and cardiac output, with a simultaneous increase in pulmonary capillary wedge pressure that leads to pulmonary edema. Definitive treatment of cardiac tamponade is pericardiocentesis or surgical pericardial drainage. In hemodynamically unstable patients, intravenous normal saline is used to stabilize the patient as a temporizing measure or bridge to definitive therapy. Despite the evidence of fluid overload, intravenous volume loading can help maintain or increase cardiac output. Low systolic blood pressure (<100 mm Hg) is the most readily accessible clinical finding that is predictive of a favorable response to volume loading.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hemodialysis: May worsen the situation by reducing the right sided filling pressures without affecting the increased intra-pericardiac pressure in tamponade.

 

Option B. Intravenous nitroglycerin: May reduce right heart filling and may worsen hypotension.

 

Option D. Right heart catheterization: May be useful for diagnosis but does not treat tamponade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Definitive treatment of cardiac tamponade is pericardiocentesis or surgical pericardial drainage.

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient presents with edema and elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP). The JVP pressure tracing is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Constrictive pericarditis

 

Option B:

 

The combination of edema, elevated JVP, and prominent x and y descents on the JVP tracing is highly suggestive of constrictive pericarditis.

 

  • Prominent x descent: This reflects the rapid atrial emptying during early ventricular systole due to the rigid pericardium limiting ventricular filling.
  • Prominent y descent: This represents the rapid ventricular filling during early diastole as the tricuspid valve opens, also due to the constraint imposed by the pericardium.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cardiac tamponade: In cardiac tamponade, the x descent is typically absent or minimal, and the y descent is blunted or slow.

 

Option C. Tricuspid regurgitation: This would cause a prominent v wave in the JVP tracing, not a prominent x descent.

 

Option D. Tricuspid stenosis: Tricuspid stenosis would cause a slow y descent, but the x descent would be normal or blunted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prominent x and y descent is characteristic of constrictive pericarditis. The prominent ‘y’ descent of constrictive pericarditis is also called as ‘friedrich sign’.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with acute chest pain, elevated CRP, and normal troponin levels. ECG is shown. Echocardiogram reveals a small pericardial effusion. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High-dose aspirin and colchicine

 

Option D:

 

ECG shows ST elevation and PR segment depression in multiple leads (II/III/aVF, V5, V6) with PR segment elevation in lead aVR.

 

The patient's clinical presentation, ECG findings, and small pericardial effusion are consistent with acute pericarditis. The elevated C-reactive protein level further supports this diagnosis. The absence of elevated troponin and normal echocardiogram rule out acute myocardial infarction.

 

The initial treatment for acute pericarditis without high-risk features (e.g., large effusion, tamponade) is high-dose aspirin or ibuprofen plus colchicine. This treatment helps to reduce inflammation and pain and prevent recurrence.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Echocardiographic-guided pericardiocentesis: Indicated for large effusions or tamponade, neither of which is present in this patient.

 

Option B. Emergent cardiac catheterization: Not necessary as the ECG findings are not consistent with ST-elevation myocardial infarction, and troponin levels are normal.

 

Option C. Exercise treadmill stress testing: Contraindicated in acute pericarditis due to the risk of exacerbating inflammation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with acute pericarditis, first-line treatment is high-dose aspirin or NSAIDs and adjuvant colchicine therapy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with pleuritic chest pain, fever, and malaise two weeks after a myocardial infarction (MI). On auscultation, you hear a multiphasic rub. His CRP levels are elevated, and troponin levels are slightly elevated but unchanged compared to previous values. ECG shows new ST elevations. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dressler's syndrome

 

Option B:

 

The patient's presentation is classic for Dressler's syndrome:

 

  • Timing: Occurs 1-8 weeks after MI.
  • Symptoms: Pleuritic chest pain, fever, malaise.
  • Exam: Pericardial friction rub.
  • Labs: Elevated CRP, slightly elevated but unchanged troponin.
  • ECG: New ST elevations (due to pericardial inflammation).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute pericarditis: Less likely given the recent MI.

 

Option C. Pulmonary embolism: Unlikely with unchanged troponin and ECG findings.

 

Option D. Recurrent MI: Unlikely with unchanged troponin and ECG findings suggestive of pericarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dressler's syndrome is a post-MI pericarditis that occurs after 1-2 weeks.

questions.text: A 38-year-old homeless man presents with TIA, fever, chills, tender splenomegaly, new painful nodules on fingers, and nits on clothes. Blood cultures are negative, but echo reveals aortic valve vegetation. What test should be sent to confirm the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bartonella serology

 

Option A:

 

This patient has culture-negative endocarditis. Culture-negative endocarditis accounts for <10% of cases in all populations.

 

A common reason for negative blood cultures is prior antibiotics. In the absence of this, the two most common pathogens are Q fever, or Coxiella burnetii (typically associated with close contact with livestock), and Bartonella. In this case, the patient’s homelessness and body louse infestation are clues for B. quintana infection.

 

Diagnosis is made by blood culture about 25% of the time. Otherwise, direct PCR of valvular tissue, if available, or acute and convalescent serologies are diagnostic options. Empirical therapy for culture-negative endocarditis usually includes ceftriaxone + gentamicin, with or without doxycycline.

 

For confirmed Bartonella endocarditis, optimal therapy is gentamicin + doxycycline

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Epstein-Barr virus heterophile antibody: EBV does not typically cause endocarditis.

 

Option C. HIV polymerase chain reaction: HIV does not cause endocarditis.

 

Option D. Q fever serology: While Q fever can cause culture-negative endocarditis, the patient's history and presentation are more consistent with Bartonella infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Two most common pathogens responsible for culture negative endocarditis re

choices.text: They are retinal hemorrhages with pale centers.
They are NOT pathognomonic for infective endocarditis.
They are due to septic emboli to the retina.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man with substance use disorder is evaluated for 3 weeks of fever and malaise and a new heart murmur. Funduscopic findings are shown. Which of the following about the finding is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) They are due to septic emboli to the retina.

 

Option D:

 

The exact pathogenesis of Roth spots is still debated, but it is thought to be related to either:

 

  • Immune complex deposition: Immune complexes formed during infective endocarditis can deposit in the retinal vessels, causing inflammation and hemorrhage.
  • Microaneurysms: The infectious process may weaken the vessel walls, leading to the formation of microaneurysms that rupture and bleed.

 

While septic emboli can also cause retinal hemorrhages, they are not the primary mechanism behind Roth spots.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. They are retinal hemorrhages with pale centers: This is the classic description of Roth spots. The pale center is thought to represent fibrin or inflammatory cells.

 

Option B. They are not pathognomonic for infective endocarditis: While Roth spots are strongly associated with infective endocarditis, they can also occur in other conditions like leukemia, HIV, anemia, diabetic/hypertensive retinopathy and vasculitis.

 

Option C. They are usually asymptomatic: Roth spots themselves do not usually cause any sympotms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Roth spots are examples of immunological manifestations of endocarditis.
